content: The Bush Administration released The Budget of the U.S. Government, Fiscal Year 2008 on February 5, 2007, as required by law. The budget documents provide detailed information on budget estimates, historical data, policy proposals, and economic forecasts from FY2007 through FY2012. Limited information is also included for FY2012 through FY2017. The Administration's policy proposals and expectations from FY2007 through FY2012, along with limited information on budget policies for FY2012 through FY2017, are discussed in the documents. They also address long-term fiscal issues, historical data on appropriations, outlays, and revenues, and the congressional budget process. Congress adopted the FY2008 budget resolution in May 2007, leading to consideration of appropriation bills by the House and Senate Appropriation Committees. In May 2007, Congress adopted the FY2008 budget resolution, leading to the consideration of appropriation bills by the House and Senate Appropriation Committees. By August 5, the House had passed all twelve regular appropriations bills, while the Senate passed some bills but failed to pass the remaining eight by the end of FY2007. Veto threats complicated the appropriations process, leading to funding extensions until December 21. Congress passed an omnibus appropriations bill (H.R. 2764) on December 19. A fourth continuing resolution was also passed, funding government operations through the end of the calendar year. The President signed the omnibus measure on December 26, providing $555 billion in discretionary budget authority for FY2008.
